AvSec Order No. 05/2022

Subject: Security procedures in respect of hold baggage screening and
its handling operations.

In exercise of powers conferred by sub-section 1A of Section SA of the
Aircraft Act, 1934 (XXII of 1934), read with Rule 3 (b) of the Aircraft
(Security) Rules, 2011, the Director General, BCAS, for the purpose of the
safety of passengers, crew, aircraft, ground personnel and the general public
in all matters related to safeguarding against acts of unlawful interference
with civil aviation, directs following Comprehensive Security Procedures in
respect of Hold Baggage screening and its handling operations to be followed
by all concerned stakeholder:

1. Scope:
Shall apply to —

a. All aircraft registered in India, and all persons on an aircraft operated
by an operator who has his principal place of business or permanent
residence in India, wherever they may be;

b. __ Indian registered aircraft operating from foreign airports and all flights
operating from Indian Airports;

c. all International and Domestic Civil Aviation Operations commencing
from any civil acrodrome/Civil Enclaves/ Regional Connectivity Scheme
Airports/ Waterdromes/ Heliport in India;

d. Airport & off-Airport locations in India, involved in Civil Aviation
operations;

e. Any other entity or location approved by the Appropriate Authority.

7. Screening Procedures:
7.1 Manual search:

i) Manual searches of hold baggage shall be conducted following the
same instructions as for cabin baggage. However, on completion of a search,
the baggage should be closed and fastened but should not, under normal
circumstances, be returned to the passenger.

ii) _ Whenever possible, manual searchers should have ready access to X-
ray facilities and ETD/EVD equipment to support their examination of
individual items. The search should be carried out at a location specified in
approved standard operating procedures. Preferably, the search should be
conducted at a location not observable by other passengers, and in a secure
and controlled environment.

ii) Manual search of the hold baggage should be conducted in
accordance with the following basic guidelines:

a) the searcher should be tactful, courteous and use caution;

b) __ it is important to adopt a systematic approach so that no items or
areas of the bag are overlooked;

c) baggage must be matched with the correct person/owner and
positioned on the search table so that the owner can open the bag, but not
interfere with the conduct of the search;

d) items found in baggage that could conceal a prohibited article should
be opened or subjected to screening by X-ray or other explosive detection
equipment.

iv) Manual search of hold baggage should preferably be conducted by
same gender especially in case of female passenger.

7.2 Explosive trace/vapour detection equipment checks: ETD/EVD
equipment to be used shall be specified by BCAS, It shall be used as part of
both primary and secondary (alarm resolution) processes. The detailed
procedure for alarm resolution is illustrated at points 12 tol4 of this order.

7.3: X-ray screening: During X-ray screening of hold baggage, X-ray
operators shall:

//RESTRICTED//

i) examine the entire X-ray image for restricted articles, or components
of restricted articles, making full and effective use of the equipment’s image
enhancement features, as appropriate. In particular, but not exclusively, the
operator should look for the components of an IED, including detonators,
wires, batteries, and electronic or mechanical timing devices. Particular
attention should be given to dense or opaque areas that might conceal
restricted articles and areas highlighted by the system as potential locations
for a threatening item;

ii) check that the shading of a baggage image is consistent throughout,
since lighter edges may indicate the presence of a sheet explosive that does
not completely line the top or bottom of the baggage;

iii) pay as much attention to the baggage framework and appendages as
to its contents; and

iv) examine any metallic or channelled part of baggage for apparent
bulges or protrusions which could partially conceal a component of an
explosive device.

7.4 If the X-ray operator is not fully satisfied that the baggage and its
contents do not contain any restricted articles or components of restricted
articles, the baggage shall undergo further examination. Under no
circumstances, the screener shall clear the baggage until he is fully satisfied
that it does not contain any restricted item/article.

7.5 Selection of hold baggage for manual search by X-ray operator should
always be made using the principle of reasoned selection and in a consistent
manner throughout the period hold baggage is being processed. Reasoned
selection means that the selection is based on the X-ray image,
concentrating the effort on those bags most likely to conceal a
prohibited /dangerous item and artfully concealed weapons/IED.

7.6 Hold baggage that cannot be cleared by the X-ray screening process
shall be referred for manual hand search and explosive detection test. Any
hold baggage which cannot be satisfactorily cleared by the total screening
process shall be denied loading into the aircraft.

7.7 It is imperative that the screening of baggage shall not cease when an
unauthorized single weapon or device is detected since multiple weapons,
devices or dangerous items can be present in a hold-baggage. There shall
also be a designated area near the screening machines for handling of
weapon and ammunitions.

8.4 Method of manual Search of Hold Baggage:

a. A manual search of bags shall be carried out physically/virtually
reuniting with their owners for further inspection and interview. Manual
hand search will be done in the physical/virtual presence of the concerned
passenger.

b. The selection of hold baggage for further inspection should be done
consistently and according to the principle of reasoned selection. Guided by
X-ray images, the focus should be on such areas of baggage which may
most likely conceal a restricted or potentially dangerous item.

c. Manual Search of an individual’s hold baggage shall be carried out as
follows but not limited to;

i. The physical inspection of hold baggage shall always be carried out in
the presence of the person presenting it/on real-time virtual CCTV Screen;

ii, Particular attention should be. paid to the lining, trim, seams, rims,
studs, zip fasteners, locks, hinges, wheels and handles to identify signs of
tampering or repair which may indicate the artfully concealment of a
prohibited article;

iii, The contents of the bag should be removed layer by layer, each being
examined until the bag is empty. The empty bag should then be lifted by
hand and assessed for balance and empty weight. If there is suspicion that
the bag is not of uniform weight, or not of a weight consistent with being
empty, the bag itself should be examined for concealment of prohibited
items, if necessary, it should be screened by X-ray;

8.5 Duration of duty time for Standalone X-ray equipment operators X-
ray image interpretation is a complex task that can be mentally demanding.
It shall be ensured that rotation of the screener is done after every 20
minutes. He/She shall resume X-Ray interoperation duties only after 40
min.

8.6 The area between the standalone screening points till check-in point
of hold baggage shall be kept under close watch by the security staff of the
concerned aircraft operator.

10. The generic four-level model is described below:

10.1 The system designed for a multi-level screening process shall have
the following features: -

10.1.1 Level 1:

@ Level 1 screening is to be undertaken by a CT-EDS machine with
automatic explosives detection facilities.

(i) All baggage images will be referred to Level 2 with suspicious areas
highlighted, if any, where a certified screener shall accept or reject the
baggage.

10.1.2 Level 2 (Level 2A and Level 2B):

i Level 2 screening is remote workstations(s) whereby operator(s) can
analyze the image generated by the Level 1 CT-EDS machine. The
workstation is required to be equipped with enhanced
imaging/manipulation systems to assist the operator to diagnose the
screened image.

ii, 100% of level 1 screened baggage images shall be referred to level 2.

iii, Whilst the bag is being referred to level 2, it should be ‘tracked’ while
it travels along the length of the conveyor such that its position and identity
are known at all times.

iv. In practice, it is usual to provide a conveying system that allows a
programmable time of up to 30 seconds to queue and process the level 2
images.

v. In the case of major airports with 5 MPPA or more, airport operators
shall install level 2B for longer time analysis, so as to ensure that Level-3 is
not overloaded. In this instance, there will be enhanced image manipulation
capabilities; Senior/experienced operator shall be deployed who shall view
the image and have more time to interpret and make a decision. At level 2B,

12. Alarm Resolution - Principles:

12.1 If an alarm is produced while conducting explosive trace/vapour
detection check; the person and/or their belongings shall be subjected to an
alarm resolution process.

12.2 When an Alarm is produced, the following actions shall be
undertaken;

12.2.1 Apply ETD cleaning or "clear down" procedures to ensure that the
equipment is free of any residual contamination, including residue from the
person or belongings from which the alarm was produced;

12.2.2 The hands of the ETD operator conducting the test and the
sampling wand, if used, should also be cleaned and tested for potential
residue, and the gloves previously used, if any, should be changed;

12.2.3. The ETD operator shall determine what item caused the alarm by
re-sampling, individually, each item, including the exact area(s) previously
sampled. To do so, a clean swab should be used for each part. Additional
screening by other methods such as X-ray equipment and/or manual search
of the items concemed may be necessary, as appropriate;

12.2.4 If, following the cleaning and re-sampling procedures, no further
alarm is produced, the hold bag should be deemed clear to proceed;

12.2.5 Ifa second positive result is produced as a result of re-sampling or
should there be other remaining concerns, appropriate escalation protocols
shall be followed. BDDS team shall be called at the spot and they shall
proceed as per the SOP.

13. Alarm Resolution - Interview:

13.1 As part of the alarm resolution process, an appropriately trained
person shall interview the person in order to help understand what may
have caused the alarm and whether this may represent a genuine cause for
concern.

13.2 _If possible, the interview should be conducted by a person with
training in behaviour awareness and questioning techniques.

14 Alarm Resolution - Clearance (When re-sampling procedure
confirms traces of Explosives):

20. Passenger and baggage reconciliation:

20.1 General Principle: Person and baggage reconciliation is a procedure
that uses a verifiable tracking system to bring attention to hold baggage that
has been loaded or is about to be loaded on a specific flight despite the
passenger’s failure to board the aircraft concerned. The benefit of this
procedure is to positively identify hold baggage that is not properly matched
with a passenger or crew member on the specific flight, and to positively
identify any passenger who has not boarded the aircraft as well as his or her
associated hold baggage. The hold baggage shall not be placed on board an
aircraft unless:

20.1.1 the hold baggage is properly marked externally to permit
reconciliation with the relevant passenger or crew member;

20.1.2 the passenger or crew member to whom the baggage belongs
has checked in for the flight on which it is to be carried;

20.1.3 prior to loading, the hold baggage is held in an area of the
airport to which only authorized persons have access;

20.1.4 the hold baggage has been identified as either accompanied or
unaccompanied;

20.1.5 the hold baggage has been cleared by screener with due
process.

20.1.6 Transfer or connecting passengers. The hold baggage of a
transfer passenger shall not be loaded unless the passenger has checked in,
where required, and boarded the onward flight, and the baggage has been
reconciled by the onward aircraft operator.

20.1.7 Disembarking transit passengers. If passengers disembark before
reaching their final destination, their hold and cabin baggage shall be
removed from the aircraft;

20.1.8 Crew members. Typically, flight and cabin crews may deliver their
own hold baggage to the aircraft. Such baggage should be accounted for on
a crew manifest that may consist of a list of names of crew members and the
number of bags each crew member has delivered, recorded against each
member’s name.

20.1.9 The process of person and baggage reconciliation may be
accomplished physically, by using a simple manual or semi-automated
system, or by using a sophisticated automated electronic system that
provides fast throughput. Airports with high volumes of passenger traffic are
advised to employ an automated system. Whichever method is used, there
should be a system of verification, monitoring and inspection to ensure that
correct reconciliation is performed, All necessary procedures shall be
completed before aircraft doors are closed. Security and other controls shall
be in place so that passengers cannot disembark undetected after boarding
and prior to aircraft pushback.

20.1.10 To facilitate effective person and baggage reconciliation, aircraft
operators should implement, in addition to baggage reconciliation
procedures, appropriate security measures for manual and automated
baggage tag stocks, in order to prevent any unauthorized use of baggage
tags. This may be achieved by instituting proper stock control and auditing
procedures.

21. Unaccompanied hold baggage:

21.1 Unaccompanied hold baggage comprises any passenger baggage
that is to be transported separately from its owner because the:

21.1.1 baggage was misdirected or delayed by another aircraft operator;
21.1.2 baggage did not reach the aircraft in time;

21.1.3 passenger departed on an earlier flight than planned; or

21.1.4 baggage missed the intended flight because of a breakdown in the
baggage handling system at some point on its journey

21.2 Security measures for un-accompanied mishandled baggage:

When an item of hold baggage is separated from its owner through
breakdown of the baggage handling system, the baggage shall be protected
from unlawful access by staff of the concerned aircraft operator and it will
be stored in a secured room provided for this purpose. The baggage will be
subjected to prescribed security controls to ensure that it does not contain
any explosive or other sabotage device, before it is loaded on to the aircraft
for transportation as unaccompanied baggage.

21.3 Unidentified baggage: means and includes a baggage at an
airport, with or without a baggage tag which is not picked up by or identified
with a passenger. Such baggage shall not be loaded into the aircraft. The
baggage shall be investigated and, if not satisfactorily accounted for, shall be
removed to an area where it cannot pose a threat or hazard and it shall be
treated as a suspect baggage.

21.4 It shall be screened or manually searched at the earliest possible
opportunity to ensure that it does not contain an explosive device or other
dangerous object or substance. All such baggage shall be held in a secure
storage facility until it has been identified by its owner or safely disposed of
in accordance with screening procedure specified by the Director General,
BCAS.

21.5 Each item of unaccompanied hold baggage must be subjected to at
least one of the following enhanced security controls:

21.5.1 Search by hand and screening through x-ray equipment from at
least two different angles in succession by the same screener.

21.5.2 _ Screening through an explosive detection system either automatic
mode or in the indicative mode i.e. where the x-ray image is presented to the
x-ray operator for assessment and decision.

21.5.3 The screener shall furnish a certificate confirming that the
unaccompanied hold baggage has been subject to the specified security
controls and the said certificate shall be attached to the unaccompanied
hold baggage portion of the manifest prior to loading in the aircraft.

21.5.4 Before screening of such baggage, aircraft operator shall give in
writing a request letter to entity conducting screening of hold baggage with

21.5.5 Each item of unaccompanied hold baggage should be accounted

21.5.6 The history of unaccompanied baggage, including the reasons

21.6 Procedures for unaccompanied baggage:

21.6.1 Baggage accepted as cargo by the aircraft operator shall be treated

21.6.2 No unidentified baggage shall be transported by air unless a
definite link can be established with a passenger who travelled and has

21.6.3 If a passenger fails to board a flight, or disembarks before

either:

() Directed to another flight on which the passenger is scheduled to

(ii) Subjected to appropriate screening before carriage, provided the
offloading was a consequence beyond the passenger’s control.

21.6.4 If a passenger travels as intended, but his or her baggage fails to

22. Application of provenance:

22.1 Provenance should be considered an acceptable means of security
control only when appropriate security measures are in place, and when the
known circumstances are clearly beyond a passenger's control. Examples of
such uncontrollable circumstances include:

22.1.1 baggage that missed the intended flight because of an unforeseen
delay during its transfer between flights or a technical factor such as the
breakdown of the baggage system or a handling error;

22.1.2 baggage that was inadvertently placed on the wrong aircraft by the
aircraft operator’s ground crew or its ground handling agent;

22.1.3 a passenger who was denied boarding because of overbooking by
the aircraft operator, but not a passenger who volunteered to give up his or
her seat as a result of overbooking; and

22.1.4 a passenger who was repositioned on another flight by the
aircraft operator as a result of a major disruption to operations caused by a
natural event such as adverse weather conditions.

22.2 _If an aircraft operator is able to establish the precise circumstances
behind the unaccompanied baggage and can ascertain that there is no
possibility that the separation was contrived by the passenger or an
accomplice, the application of provenance may be appropriate.

22.3 In applying provenance as a security control, the aircraft operator
should establish that the passenger did in fact travel on the flight for which
he or she checked in or, alternatively, was repositioned on a different flight
or re-routed solely at the prerogative of the aircraft operator and not at the
passenger’s request.

22.4 The circumstances pertaining to unaccompanied baggage should be
recorded in an audit trail by a trained and authorized employee of the
aircraft operator/GHA before the baggage is loaded onto an aircraft.

22.5 An aircraft operator accepting unaccompanied baggage from another
operator should obtain a written record of the security controls and
screening applied to the transferred baggage, and a history of the
passenger's travel itinerary and/or baggage claim report, before accepting it
for onward carriage.

22.6 Unless unaccompanied baggage has been previously screened to the
required standard and has become separated from its owner as a result of
factors clearly beyond the passenger's control, all unaccompanied hold
baggage, both originating and transfer, para shall be treated as unclear
baggage.

26.1.10 The baggage containing fire-arm will be made over to the
passenger at the destination in the arrival hall and not on the tarmac.

26.1.11 In case of in-line hold baggage screening system, the process will
be performed in a secure area earmarked for this purpose at the airport by
the airport operator concerned.

26.2 Procedure and Actions during detection of prohibited articles:

26.2.1 The dangerous goods and prohibited articles shall not be allowed
for carriage on persons or in hold baggage. These will be seized by the
screening officer.

26.2.2 It is important for the searcher to remain calm and not cause a
panic among other passengers, which may make the situation worse.

26.2.3 The searcher’s supervisor should seek further assistance from the
ASG/local police.

26.2.4 If the item is confirmed as a suspect explosive device DO NOT
TOUCH IT but carry out standard suspect explosive device procedures.

a) Operator should remain cool and calm, and should not panic
b) Stop the conveyor belt.

c) Notify the supervisor by a pre-arranged signal

d) Notify the ASG/local police.

€) Do not try to restrain the passenger by using physical force
{) Do not allow the passenger to board the aircraft.

g) Evacuate the general area

h) Request for services of BDDS.

26.2.5 In the case of an undeclared weapon or explosive device being
detected during the screening process at hold baggage screening check
point, the relevant person shall be detained by the screening officer and
handed over to local police for further action.

26.3 Course of Action:

26.3.1 Authorized arms and /or ammunition are allowed to be carried
only in the hold of an aircraft. If passenger failed to declared the arms and
/or ammunition and arms and /or ammunition following course of action
shall be followed:

a) Operator should remain cool and calm, and should not panic.
b) Remove the baggage for physical checking.

c) Don't allow the passenger to get hold of the baggage.

d) Question the passenger whether he is carrying any prohibited items.

e) In case the passenger answers positively about the weapon ask the
passenger to show his weapon license.

i, If the passenger is having a valid license with him, the ASG
(CISF/ state Police) /Aircraft operator/ Airport operator security staff, as the
case may be, shall examine the weapon physically to see that it is unloaded
and packed as per the prescribed norms, obtain declaration from the
Passenger as required under the Aircraft (Carriage of Dangerous Goods)
Rules 2003 and thereafter allow him to proceed for check-in etc. There is no
need to detain the passenger. However, a complaint shall be made about the
incident to the Director General, DGCA for necessary action at their end
under the Aircraft (Carriage of Dangerous Goods) Rules 2003. Local police
shall also be informed.

ii. If the passenger does not have a valid arms license with him at that
time but claims to possess the same, he cannot be allowed to proceed. The
passenger along with his baggage shall be detained and handed over to local
police for necessary legal action in this regard.

iii. If the passenger claims that he is a serving Police/Defence
Services/Central Armed Forces personnel and is entitled to carry his service
arms and ammunition, the ASG (CISF/ state Police) /Aircraft operator /
Airport operator security staff shall confirm his identity through a valid
photo identity card issued by the Department / Ministry concerned and
movement order/authority slip. If his identity and bona fides are beyond
doubt, the ASG (CISF/ state Police) / Aircraft operator / Airport operator
security staff can obtain necessary declaration from him as required under
the Aircraft (Carriage of Dangerous Goods) Rules 2003 and thereafter allow
him to proceed for check-in etc. There is no need to detain the passenger.
However, a complaint shall be made about the incident to the Director
General, DGCA for necessary action at their end under the Aircraft (Carriage
of Dangerous Goods) Rules 2003. Local police shall also be informed and a

27. Prohibition on carriage of certain goods:

27.1 Carriage of Drone - Drone/Remotely Piloted Aircraft System (RPAS)
/Unmanned Aircraft System (UAS) /Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) are
restricted items and may be carried in hold baggage if appropriate approval
is in place.

27.2 Carriage of Firecracker / Pyrotechnics:

27.2.1 Firecrackers/pyrotechnics contain explosives and carriage of
explosives in check-in baggage is prohibited under Rule 8 of Aircraft Rules,
1937.

27.2.2 All aircraft operators/Airport operator shall ensure that any
attempt by passengers to smuggle explosives including fire crackers into the
aircraft is not only foiled but the passengers involved in such acts are also
handed over to the police and FIR is lodged against such passengers for
appropriate action. Mere confiscation of firecrackers detected in the check-in
baggage and subsequent letting off of such passengers are not enough. Legal
action against such passengers is essential to prevent unlawful interferences
with civil aviation operations.

27.2.3 All travelling public may be suitably educated on the above lines by
way of warning mentioned in the airlines ticket and by display of boards in
terminal buildings. Stringent punishment to offenders alone will act as
deterrent against potential offenders.

27.3 Carriage of Satellite Phone:

27.3.1 BSNL has been issued a ‘Sui Generis’ license by the DoT for
providing Global Satellite Phone Service with M/s Inmarsat. Accordingly, the
use of BSNL provided Inmarsat satellite handset (SAT phone) has been
allowed in India and the customers availing this service are required to show
authorization of the handset, whenever asked by security personnel.

27.3.2 Use of all other satellite phone services such as Thuraya etc.

continues to be unlawful in Indian Territory, unless specific permission is
given by the competent authority for use of such service. Unauthorized use

28. Procedure on Failure of Security Controls of hold baggage: In the
event that an aircraft has already departed without the proper
implementation of security controls related to the flight, appropriate
authorities at the destination of arrival shall be notified as to the nature of
the failure.

29. Procedure on Power failure and break down of security
Equipment:

Power failure and break down of security equipment: Every airport
operator shall be responsible to make necessary arrangements for alternate
power source to ensure that prescribed security checks are carried out
without disruption. In case of breakdown of security equipment, 100%
manual screening shall be carried out.

30 Exemptions: DG, BCAS may exempt screening of hold baggage in
Civil Aircraft operating from and to civil airports in India in national interest.
